questions.text: Which of the following hormones is secreted by the zona glomerulosa?
questions.solution:
The zona glomerulosa secretes aldosterone.

The adrenal cortex has three zones. From outer to inner, they are:

  • Zona glomerulosa: Secretes mineralocorticoids (Aldosterone)
  • Zona fasiculata: Secretes glucocorticoids (Cortisol and corticosterone)
  • Zona reticularis: Secretes sex steroids (dehydroepiandrosterone, androstenedione, estrogens, and glucocorticoids)

The adrenal medulla secretes catecholamines.

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for the formation of estradiol?
questions.solution:
11β hydroxylase is not required for estradiol synthesis. 

11β hydroxylase is required for the conversion of 11-deoxycorticosterone to corticosterone, a compound formed in the mineralocorticoid synthesis pathway.

questions.text: Which of the following is statements is false?

choices.text: 90% of the cortisol is bound to plasma proteins
Cortisol has a half-life of 60-90 minutes.
Aldosterone has a half-life of about 20 minutes.
80% of the aldosterone is bound to plasma proteins

questions.solution:
60% of aldosterone is bound to plasma proteins, not 80%. 

90% of cortisol is bound to plasma proteins. Most of it is bound to transcortin, a corticosteroid-specific α2 globulin, and the rest to albumin. This high degree of binding to plasma proteins slows the elimination of cortisol. Therefore, cortisol has a longer half-life of 60 to 90 minutes.

Since only about 60% of aldosterone is in bound form, it has a relatively short half-life of about 20 minutes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an action of cortisol?
questions.solution:
Cortisol suppresses the proliferation of T-lymphocytes and decreases the number of T-Lymphocytes.

Actions of Cortisol: 

Metabolic effects:

  • Effect on carbohydrates: Exert an anti-insulin effect, leading to hyperglycemia
    • Increases gluconeogenesis
    • Increases glycogen synthesis
    • Decreases utilization of glucose in peripheral tissues
  • Effect on fat and appetite: promotes mobilization of fatty acids from adipose tissue in acute states. This mobilization increases the concentration of free fatty acids in the plasma, which also increases their utilization for energy, causing lipolysis. However, in chronic states cortisol increases appetite and food intake by inducing the synthesis of neuropeptide-Y which leads to an apparent lipogenic effect seen as buffalo humping and central obesity.
  • Effect on protein: Exerts a catabolic effect and causes proteolysis
  • Effect on water and electrolytes: Sodium water retention and diuresis

Anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects:

  • Induce the synthesis of lipocortin, an inhibitor of phospholipase A2
  • Inhibit the release of histamine and serotonin 
  • Inhibit the production of IL-2 and T lymphocytes, and depress cellular immunity 

Maintenance of vascular responsiveness to catecholamines:

  • Cortisol up-regulates α1 receptors on arterioles, increasing their sensitivity to the vasoconstrictor effect of norepinephrine

questions.text: All of the following conditions increase cortisol except ______
questions.solution:
Cortisol secretion is low during sleep.

Any type of stress, physical or mental, can increase cortisol release.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is being treated for severe COVID with dexamethasone. Which of the following mechanisms best explain the rationale for starting steroids in this patient?
questions.solution:
Inhibition of phospholipase A2 is an anti-inflammatory effect of steroids, thus being the rationale for starting steroids in this patient.

Patients with severe COVID are at high risk of developing a systemic inflammatory response. Steroids help in mitigating these deleterious effects. 

Phospholipase A2 is a precursor of arachidonic acid. Arachidonic acid is the precursor for prostaglandins and leukotrienes, which are involved in inflammation. Steroids induce the synthesis of lipocortin, which inhibits phospholipase A2. 

Other anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects of steroids are: 

  • Inhibit the production of interleukin-2 (IL-2) and proliferation of T lymphocytes
  • Inhibit the release of histamine and serotonin from mast cells and platelets

questions.text: Which of the following effects is produced only at high levels of glucocorticoids?

choices.text: Increased excretion of a water load

questions.solution:
Inhibition of inflammatory response requires high levels of glucocorticoids. 

Anti-inflammatory and anti-allergic responses (inhibition of histamine from mast cells and basophils) are produced only at high levels of glucocorticoids. These effects cannot be produced by normal circulating glucocorticoids in the body and thus require exogenous supplementation of steroids to produce them.

questions.text: ACTH level is higher during______
questions.solution:
ACTH level is higher during the early morning and low during late evening. 75% of the ACTH production occurs between 4:00 AM to 10:00 AM. 

Note: Cortisol levels are also high in the early morning and low in the late evening.

questions.text: ACTH secretion is inhibited by______
questions.solution: Glucocorticoids inhibit ACTH secretion by a direct negative feedback mechanism. They also inhibit CRH secretion.

questions.text: Aldosterone secretion is maximally stimulated by______
questions.solution: Hyperkalemia and activation of renin-angiotensin system are the most potent stimulators of aldosterone secretion.

questions.text: Mineralocorticoid receptors are present in all  except______
questions.solution:
Mineralocorticoid receptors are not present in the liver. They are present in kidneys, colon, hippocampus, salivary glands, and sweat glands. 

Mineralocorticoid activity increases the reabsorption of Na+ and potassium excretion from urine, sweat, saliva, and contents of the colon. Along with the Na+, there is water reabsorption and inturn ECF volume expansion.

questions.text: In which of the following ways does aldosterone react with renal tubular cells?

choices.text: Increases transport of ENaCs from the cytoplasm to the cell membrane
Binds to steroid receptor inside the nucleus of renal tubular cells
Binds to ENaC's on the cell membrane and increase Na+ transport
Binds to G-protien coupled receptors on the cell surface

questions.solution:
Aldosterone increases transport of ENaCs (epithelial sodium channels) from the cytoplasm to the cell membrane. This is a rapid effect of aldosterone. 

Mechanism of action of aldosterone:

  • Aldosterone diffuses into the renal tubular epithelial cells and combines with a miner­alocorticoid receptor (MR) in the cytoplasm.
  • The aldosterone-receptor complex diffuses into the nucleus and induces transcription. 
  • The mRNA diffuses back into the cytoplasm and undergoes translation to form proteins. These have two effects - Rapid and Slow.
  • The slower effect is increase in synthesis of ENaCs.
  • The important products formed are:
    • Na+K+ATPase 
    • membrane transport proteins like epithelial sodium channel

questions.text: Which of the following has the greatest effect on plasma osmolality?
questions.solution:
Vasopressin (also called ADH or anti-diuretic hormone) has the greatest effect on plasma osmolality.

Two primary systems are especially involved in regulating the concentration of sodium and osmolarity of extracellular fluid:

  • The osmoreceptor-ADH system and
  • The thirst mechanism. 

Although aldosterone decreases the rate of sodium excretion by the kidneys, the concentration of sodium in the extracellular fluid rises only by a few mEqs. The reason for this is that when sodium is reabsorbed by the tubules, simultaneous absorption of equivalent amounts of water occurs. So, aldosterone does not cause a significant change in the plasma osmolality.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is admitted with nausea, vomiting, and dizziness. On evaluation, he is hypotensive and has mucosal hyperpigmentation. Laboratory workup reveals the diagnosis of hypoaldosteronism. Which of the following is least likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with hypoaldosteronism, alkalosis is least likely to be found. Hypoaldosteronism is rather responsible for causing metabolic acidosis.

Patients with hypoaldosteronism have:

  • Hyponatremia- due to increased Na+ loss in urine 
  • Hyperkalemia- due to K+ retention 
  • Hypotension- due to reduced ECF volume 
  • Mild metabolic acidosis because hydrogen ions are not secreted in the urine

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the OPD with headaches and high blood pressure. On investigation,  increased aldosterone levels with low renin levels are seen and a diagnosis of Conn's syndrome is made. Which of the following is least likely to be found in this patient?

choices.text: Rise of  > 7meq/L in plasma Na+ level

questions.solution:
Rise in plasma Na+ level of > 7meq/L than the normal value is least likely to be found in this patient.

Excess secretion of aldosterone causes only a modest increase in plasma sodium, usually a rise of less than 4-6 mEq/L. When sodium gets reabsorbed, water also accompanies it, resulting in plasma sodium remaining fairly normal.

Conn’s syndrome or primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-producing tumour of the zona glomerulosa, causing:

  • Loss of potassium by the kidneys leads to hypokalemia.
  • Mild metabolic alkalosis.
  • A slight increase in extracellular fluid volume and blood volume.
  • A modest increase in plasma sodium concentration.
  • Hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following decreases aldosterone secretion?
questions.solution: Hypernatremia decreases aldosterone secretion.

questions.text: Hormones that are increased in plasma during periods of stress include all of the following except _______
questions.solution:
Insulin does not increase during stress. 

In response to stress, the usual physiological functions like gluconeogenesis, lipolysis, and inhibition of insulin actions occurs, resulting in increased blood levels of fuel sources (glucose, fatty acids) needed to cope. 

Hormones that are increased in the blood by stress are CRH, ACTH, cortisol, β-endorphin(to reduce pain), vasopressin, aldosterone, growth hormone, and glucagon.

questions.text: Which of the following is the major adrenal androgen ?
questions.solution:
Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) is the major adrenal androgen. 

The androgens secreted from the adrenal gland are dehydroepiandrosterone and androstenedione.

questions.text: A 16-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with hirsutism and masculinization. Which of the following hormones of the adrenal cortex is the likely culprit?
questions.solution:
Hirsutism and masculinization in a female suggest excessive androgens like dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA).

Adrenogenital syndrome is due to an adrenocortical tumor secreting excessive quantities of androgens that cause intense masculinizing effects.  In boys, it presents as precocious puberty. In women, virile characteristics develop, including:

  • Growth of a beard
  • Deeper voice
  • Masculine distribution of hair on the body and the pubis and
  • Growth of the clitoris

The excretion of 17-ketosteroids (which are derived from androgens) in the urine maybe 10 to 15 times elevated. This finding can be used in diagnosing the disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is not directly controlled by ACTH?
questions.solution:
The secretion of the adrenal medullary hormones (epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine) is not controlled directly by ACTH.

  Hormones secreted Regulated by
Zona glomerulosa Mineralocorticoids (aldosterone) Angiotensin II, K+, ACTH (mild transient effect)
Zona fasiculata Glucocorticoids (cortisol, corticosterone) ACTH
Zona reticularis Sex steroids (DHEA, DHEA-S) ACTH
Adrenal medulla Catecholamines (epinephrine, norepinephrine) Diffuse sympathetic discharge(stress)

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is exclusively secreted by adrenal gland but not by the ovaries of females?
questions.solution:
DHEAS is exclusively secreted from the adrenals but not by ovaries because ovaries lack the enzyme dehydroepiandrosterone-sulphotransferase needed to form DHEAS. 

90% of DHEA is synthesised by the adrenals and 10% comes from the ovaries.
